moves.4. exd5 Qxd5: ...which we exchange, bringing my queen into play.
moves.6. Bd2 Bxc3 7. Bxc3: ...which I remove, in exchange for my bishop, therefore removing that threat to the queen.
moves.7... Nf6 8. Qe2 O-O 9. O-O-O: Castling exposed my opponent's far left-hand pawn...
moves.9... Qxa2: ...so I snaffle it with my queen, opening up that far side, and my queen is in a position to potentially cause panic.
moves.10. Kd2 Rd8: Moving my rook keeps the pawn in front of the king to its file, to line up and assault of the king, with my f6 knight...
moves.11. g3 Bf5: ...and I bring out the bishop to cover the e4 square, in order to protect the knight from the queen...
moves.12. Bg2 Ne4+: ... so now my knight is protected by the rook and the bishop...
moves.13. Ke1 Nxc3 14. bxc3: ...and I can remove the bishop in exchange for my knight...
moves.17... g6: This was to make sure that if I did lose my bishop, the knight would follow...
moves.19. Bxc6 bxc6: ...and the reverse happened here. It's now seven pawns against five, with two rooks apiece.
moves.20. f3 Rab8 21. Kf2 Rb2: I decide to use this rook as an attacker...
moves.22. Re1 Rd5: ...and this in the middle of the board.
moves.28. Re2 a4: I go for a promotion attempt...
moves.29. Re8+ Kf7: ...but I get given a wake-up call.
moves.41... h5 42. Rh4 Rg5 43. Rh3 Kd7: Time to bring my king into play...
moves.44. Rxg3 Rxg3+ 45. Kxg3: ...as the rooks are now gone, and it's two pawns against one.
moves.45... c5: Thought I'd get my c-pawn moving to the fourth rank, in order to "confuse" the king.
Now the game's mine to lose...
moves.50. Kf3 Kd2: ...as my pawn has a clear run.
